hints_html:
What fact about the proportions of the stalagmite can you use to relate the variables r and h? Once you have done this, you can write the volume formula either in terms of h (for part i) or r (for part ii).

Try differentiating the equation relating h and r. What does this tell you about the relationship between \(dh/dt\) and \(dr/dt\)?
hints_latex:
What fact about the proportions of the stalagmite can you use to relate
the variables \emph{r} and \emph{h}? Once you have done this, you can
write the volume formula either in terms of \emph{h} (for part i) or
\emph{r} (for part ii).

Try differentiating the equation relating \emph{h} and \emph{r}. What
does this tell you about the relationship between $dh/dt$ and $dr/dt$?
hints_raw:
What fact about the proportions of the stalagmite can you use to relate the variables ''r'' and ''h''?  Once you have done this, you can write the volume formula either in terms of ''h'' (for part i) or ''r'' (for part ii).
Try differentiating the equation relating ''h'' and ''r''.  What does this tell you about the relationship between <math>dh/dt</math> and <math>dr/dt</math>?
sols_html:
We are given the volume of a cone.

\[\begin{aligned} V = \frac13 \pi r^2 h\end{aligned}\]

If we differentiate this expression as it is, we will end up with an expression relating \(dV/dt\) to both variables of r and h. To avoid this, we need to write the volume formula in terms of just r or h, by writing one variable in terms of another. The question states that the length of the stalagmite is always five times its radius, so we can write \(h = 5r\), or, alternatively, \(r = h/5\).

(i) Finding an expression in terms of h: Using \(r = h/5\), we plug it into our volume formula to get

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \frac13 \pi \left(\frac{h}{5}\right)^2 h\\ &= \frac13 \pi \frac{h^3}{25} \end{aligned}\]

Differentiating yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{dt} &= \frac13 \pi \frac{3h^2}{25}\frac{dh}{dt}\\ &= \frac{\pi h^2}{25} \frac{dh}{dt} \end{aligned}\]

And because we know that \(dh/dt = 0.13\) mm/year, we finally reach an expression relating the rate of change in volume to the height h

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{\pi h^2}{25} 0.13\end{aligned}\]

(ii) Finding an expression in terms of r: To find an expression in terms of r we simply use the relationship h = 5r to get

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \frac13 \pi r^2 (5r)\\ &= \frac53 \pi r^3 \end{aligned}\]

Differentiating yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{dt} &= \frac53 \pi 3r^2 \frac{dr}{dt}\\ &= 5\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt} \end{aligned}\]

To find an expression for \(dV/dt\) solely in terms of \(r\), we need to find \(dr/dt\). We can do this by differentiating the equation \(h = 5r\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dh}{dt} = 5\frac{dr}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{0.13}{5} = \frac{dr}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

Plugging this into our formula for \(dV/dt\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{dt} &= 5\pi r^2 \frac{0.13}{5} \\ &= \pi 0.13 r^2\end{aligned}\]

in terms of r, as desired.
sols_raw:
We are given the volume of a cone.  

: <math>V = \frac13 \pi r^2 h</math>

If we differentiate this expression as it is, we will end up with an expression relating <math>dV/dt</math> to both variables of ''r'' and ''h''.  To avoid this, we need to write the volume formula in terms of just ''r'' or ''h'', by writing one variable in terms of another.  The question states that the length of the stalagmite is always five times its radius, so we can write <math>h  = 5r</math>, or, alternatively, <math>r = h/5</math>.  

''(i) Finding an expression in terms of h'': Using <math>r = h/5</math>, we plug it into our volume formula to get

: <math>\begin{align}
V &= \frac13 \pi \left(\frac{h}{5}\right)^2 h\\
&= \frac13 \pi \frac{h^3}{25} 
\end{align}</math>

Differentiating yields

: <math>\begin{align}
\frac{dV}{dt} &= \frac13 \pi \frac{3h^2}{25}\frac{dh}{dt}\\
&= \frac{\pi h^2}{25} \frac{dh}{dt} 
\end{align}</math>

And because we know that <math>dh/dt = 0.13</math> mm/year, we finally reach an expression relating the rate of change in volume to the height ''h''

: <math> \frac{dV}{dt} = \frac{\pi h^2}{25} 0.13</math>

''(ii) Finding an expression in terms of r'': To find an expression in terms of ''r'' we simply use the relationship ''h = 5r'' to get

: <math>\begin{align}
V &= \frac13 \pi r^2 (5r)\\
&= \frac53 \pi r^3 
\end{align}</math>

Differentiating yields

: <math>\begin{align}
\frac{dV}{dt} &= \frac53 \pi 3r^2 \frac{dr}{dt}\\
&= 5\pi r^2\frac{dr}{dt} 
\end{align}</math>

To find an expression for <math>dV/dt</math> solely in terms of <math>r</math>, we need to find <math>dr/dt</math>.  We can do this by differentiating the equation <math>h = 5r</math> to get

:<math>\frac{dh}{dt} = 5\frac{dr}{dt} </math>
:<math>\frac{0.13}{5} = \frac{dr}{dt}</math>

Plugging this into our formula for <math>dV/dt</math> gives 

: <math> \begin{align}\frac{dV}{dt} &= 5\pi r^2 \frac{0.13}{5} \\
&= \pi 0.13 r^2\end{align}</math>

in terms of ''r'', as desired.
statement_html:
Stalagmites are cone-shaped mineral deposits which rise from the floors of limestone caves. They form over millenia as dripping water deposits calcium carbonate onto the cave floor.

Consider a cone-shaped stalagmite with a length always equal to five times its radius. Suppose the stalagmite’s height increases at a rate of 0.13 millimetres per year. Write down two expressions for the rate of change of its volume: (i) with respect to its height h, and (ii) with respect to its radius r.

Hint: the volume V of a cone with radius r and height h is equal to \(\frac13 \pi r^2h\).
statement_latex:
Stalagmites are cone-shaped mineral deposits which rise from the floors
of limestone caves. They form over millenia as dripping water deposits
calcium carbonate onto the cave floor.

Consider a cone-shaped stalagmite with a length always equal to five
times its radius. Suppose the stalagmite's height increases at a rate of
0.13 millimetres per year. Write down two expressions for the rate of
change of its volume: \emph{(i)} with respect to its height \emph{h},
and \emph{(ii)} with respect to its radius \emph{r}.

Hint: the volume \emph{V} of a cone with radius \emph{r} and height
\emph{h} is equal to $\frac13 \pi r^2h$.
statement_raw:
Stalagmites are cone-shaped mineral deposits which rise from the floors of limestone caves. They form over millenia as dripping water deposits calcium carbonate onto the cave floor.

Consider a cone-shaped stalagmite with a length always equal to five times its radius. Suppose the stalagmite's height increases at a rate of 0.13 millimetres per year. Write down two expressions for the rate of change of its volume: ''(i)'' with respect to its height ''h'', and ''(ii)'' with respect to its radius ''r''.

Hint: the volume ''V'' of a cone with radius ''r'' and height ''h'' is equal to <math>\frac13 \pi r^2h</math>.
